title: Isaiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 6.

questions.question: In the year that which king died did Isaiah see the Lord sitting upon a throne?
options: King Uzziah
King Hezekiah
King David
King Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: King Uzziah
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:1 states, 'In the year that king Uzziah died I saw also the Lord sitting upon a throne...'

questions.question: How many wings did each seraphim have according to Isaiah 6?
options: Six
Four
Two
Eight
questions.correctAnswer: Six
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:2 says, 'each one had six wings; with twain he covered his face, and with twain he covered his feet, and with twain he did fly.'

questions.question: What did the seraphims cry to one another?
options: Holy, holy, holy, is the LORD of hosts
Glory to God in the highest
Blessed be the name of the Lord
The Lord reigns forever
questions.correctAnswer: Holy, holy, holy, is the LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:3 records the seraphims crying, 'Holy, holy, holy, is the LORD of hosts: the whole earth is full of his glory.'

questions.question: What happened to the door posts at the voice of the one crying?
options: They moved
They broke
They glowed
They remained still
questions.correctAnswer: They moved
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:4 says, 'And the posts of the door moved at the voice of him that cried...'

questions.question: What did Isaiah say about himself when he saw the Lord?
options: Woe is me! for I am undone
I am blessed
I am worthy
I am strong
questions.correctAnswer: Woe is me! for I am undone
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:5 states, 'Then said I, Woe is me! for I am undone; because I am a man of unclean lips...'

questions.question: What did one of the seraphims take from the altar to touch Isaiah's lips?
options: A live coal
A golden censer
A scroll
A trumpet
questions.correctAnswer: A live coal
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:6 says, 'Then flew one of the seraphims unto me, having a live coal in his hand, which he had taken with the tongs from off the altar.'

questions.question: What was the purpose of the live coal touching Isaiah's lips?
options: To take away his iniquity and purge his sin
To give him strength
To mark him as a prophet
To heal his eyes
questions.correctAnswer: To take away his iniquity and purge his sin
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:7 states, 'Lo, this hath touched thy lips; and thine iniquity is taken away, and thy sin purged.'

questions.question: What was Isaiah's response when the Lord asked, 'Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?'
options: Here am I; send me
I am not worthy
Send another
I will think about it
questions.correctAnswer: Here am I; send me
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:8 records Isaiah's response, 'Then said I, Here am I; send me.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 6, what were the people told to do, though they would not understand or perceive?
options: Hear indeed but understand not, and see indeed but perceive not
Pray and fast
Repent and be saved
Sing praises to the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Hear indeed but understand not, and see indeed but perceive not
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:9 says, 'Go, and tell this people, Hear ye indeed, but understand not; and see ye indeed, but perceive not.'

questions.question: What did the Lord say He would make the heart of the people?
options: Fat
Humble
Open
Pure
questions.correctAnswer: Fat
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:10 states, 'Make the heart of this people fat, and make their ears heavy, and shut their eyes.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah asked the Lord how long the desolation would last.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:11 says, 'Then said I, Lord, how long? And he answered...'

questions.question: True or False: The Lord said the land would be utterly desolate and the cities wasted without inhabitant.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:11 confirms the land desolation and cities wasted without inhabitants.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 6 says the whole earth is empty and void.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:3 says the whole earth is full of His glory, not empty and void.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'But yet in it shall be a tenth, and it shall return, and shall be eaten: as a ____, and as an oak, whose substance is in them...'
options: teil tree
pine tree
cedar tree
olive tree
questions.correctAnswer: teil tree
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:13 uses the example of a 'teil tree' and an oak to describe what remains after destruction.

questions.question: Who removed men far away causing a great forsaking in the midst of the land?
options: The LORD
The king
The prophets
The enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:12 says, 'And the LORD have removed men far away, and there be a great forsaking in the midst of the land.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 6 teach us about humility when faced with God's holiness?
options: Recognize our unworthiness and confess our sin
Boast in our good deeds before God
Ignore our faults and focus on others' sins
Deny God's holiness to avoid fear
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize our unworthiness and confess our sin
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:5 shows Isaiah's response to seeing the Lord: he says, 'Woe is me! for I am undone; because I am a man of unclean lips.' This teaches us to humble ourselves before God's holiness by acknowledging our sinfulness. This theme is consistent with verses 6-7 where cleansing from sin is shown as necessary for serving God.

questions.question: What does Isaiah's vision of the seraphims covering their faces and feet teach about reverence before God?
options: It demonstrates deep respect and awe for God's holiness
It shows they are ashamed of their duties
It means they are hiding from God's presence
It implies they are reluctant to serve
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates deep respect and awe for God's holiness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:2 describes seraphims covering their faces and feet with wings as an act of reverence. This teaches believers to approach God with awe and respect, recognizing His majesty and holiness (verses 1-3).

questions.question: How does the call of Isaiah in this chapter inspire us in evangelism and obedience?
options: To willingly volunteer when God calls us
To avoid difficult tasks and wait for easier ones
To only serve when we feel fully prepared
To argue with God about our mission
questions.correctAnswer: To willingly volunteer when God calls us
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 6:8, when God asks 'Whom shall I send?', Isaiah responds, 'Here am I; send me.' This shows the importance of eagerness and readiness to obey God's call in sharing the Gospel, despite challenges (verses 9-10).

questions.question: A believer struggles with feeling spiritually dull and unresponsive. According to Isaiah 6, what spiritual condition might this reflect?
options: A hardened heart and closed eyes and ears to God’s word
An abundance of faith and understanding
A joyful and receptive spirit
Complete spiritual enlightenment
questions.correctAnswer: A hardened heart and closed eyes and ears to God’s word
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:9-10 explains that sometimes the heart becomes 'fat,' ears 'heavy,' and eyes 'shut,' meaning a spiritual dullness or resistance to God's message. Recognizing this condition is the first step toward repentance and renewed openness.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 6 encourage believers to trust God in times of desolation or trials?
options: By reminding them of God’s preservation of a faithful remnant
By promising immediate relief from problems
By instructing them to isolate from others
By denying the reality of hardship
questions.correctAnswer: By reminding them of God’s preservation of a faithful remnant
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:13 speaks of a tenth remaining and becoming the holy seed, symbolizing God's preservation of a faithful remnant even amid judgment and desolation, encouraging trust and perseverance.

questions.question: What practical lesson about confession and forgiveness can we learn from the coal touching Isaiah’s lips?
options: Confession leads to cleansing and removal of sin
Sin can be ignored if we try hard enough
Forgiveness is unnecessary for service
We must earn forgiveness by works alone
questions.correctAnswer: Confession leads to cleansing and removal of sin
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:6-7 describes a seraph touching Isaiah’s lips with a coal, symbolizing purification from sin. This teaches the believer the importance of confessing sin and receiving God's cleansing to serve Him effectively.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 6 challenge believers to respond when God sends them to proclaim difficult messages?
options: To obey faithfully, even if the message is hard to hear
To refuse if the people are disobedient
To soften the message to gain approval
To wait until all circumstances are perfect
questions.correctAnswer: To obey faithfully, even if the message is hard to hear
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 instruct Isaiah to tell people things they won’t understand or accept, teaching that obedience to God’s call includes faithfully delivering His message regardless of the audience’s response.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah’s vision teaches us that God’s presence can bring conviction that leads to repentance and service.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:1-8 shows that encountering God's holiness brought Isaiah deep conviction of sin (verse 5), cleansing (verses 6-7), and a willing heart to serve (verse 8), illustrating the transformative power of God’s presence.

questions.question: In Isaiah 6, what does the phrase 'the whole earth is full of his glory' teach about God’s sovereign presence in daily life?
options: God’s glory is everywhere and should inspire our worship and integrity
God is only present in holy places
God’s glory is hidden from believers
The earth is full of human glory, not God’s
questions.correctAnswer: God’s glory is everywhere and should inspire our worship and integrity
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:3 says, 'the whole earth is full of his glory,' reminding believers that God's presence permeates all life, motivating faithful living and worship in all circumstances.

questions.question: How can a family apply the teaching from Isaiah 6 about acknowledging sin and seeking God's cleansing?
options: By regularly confessing faults and asking God for forgiveness together
By ignoring conflicts and hoping they resolve on their own
By blaming others without self-reflection
By avoiding spiritual conversations
questions.correctAnswer: By regularly confessing faults and asking God for forgiveness together
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:5-7 shows the importance of recognizing uncleanliness and receiving God's purging. Families can apply this by fostering an environment of confession and mutual forgiveness to grow in holiness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 6, God’s judgment means complete destruction without hope for restoration.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:11-13 describes severe judgment and desolation but also promises a remnant (a tenth) that will return and thrive, demonstrating God’s mercy and hope beyond judgment.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by unworthiness in service to God. Based on Isaiah 6, what truth can encourage them?
options: God cleanses our sin and enables us to serve
Only perfect people can serve God
Service is only for the spiritually elite
Unworthiness disqualifies us permanently
questions.correctAnswer: God cleanses our sin and enables us to serve
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:6-7 illustrates how God purified Isaiah’s lips, showing that God’s cleansing removes barriers so believers can serve Him despite their imperfections.

questions.question: How does the imagery of 'a live coal from the altar' in Isaiah 6 relate to personal spiritual renewal?
options: It symbolizes God’s purifying power to renew and sanctify
It represents punishment without hope
It is a symbol of destruction only
It means complete isolation from others
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God’s purifying power to renew and sanctify
questions.explanation: The live coal in Isaiah 6:6-7 symbolizes God’s cleansing fire that purifies the believer’s sin and empowers renewed service, teaching the importance of spiritual renewal.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 6 teaches that even in times of judgment and desolation, _______ will remain as a holy remnant.
options: a tenth
all people
no one
the entire city
questions.correctAnswer: a tenth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:13 states that a tenth will remain and become the holy seed, teaching that God preserves a faithful remnant for restoration.

questions.question: What lesson about prayer and seeking God’s guidance can we learn from Isaiah’s response to God’s question in Isaiah 6?
options: We should respond eagerly and willingly when God calls
We should ignore God’s call if unsure
We should question God’s decisions endlessly
We should wait for others to respond first
questions.correctAnswer: We should respond eagerly and willingly when God calls
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:8 shows Isaiah immediately volunteering, 'Here am I; send me,' demonstrating the importance of prompt, willing response in prayer and obedience.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Isaiah 6:1, the vision of the Lord sitting upon a throne is closely associated with which Old Testament concept of divine kingship?
options: The enthronement of Yahweh as King over all the earth
The coronation of King David
The establishment of Solomon's temple
The exile of Israel to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The enthronement of Yahweh as King over all the earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:1 presents a theophany where Yahweh is depicted as a sovereign King on a high throne, reflecting the ancient Near Eastern motif of divine kingship, affirming God's supreme authority over all creation.

questions.question: The seraphims described in Isaiah 6:2 have six wings. What is the symbolic significance of the wings covering the face and feet in the context of ancient Near Eastern worship?
options: Reverence for God's holiness and humility before His presence
The ability to fly swiftly between heaven and earth
To shield themselves from human gaze
To hide their identity from other angels
questions.correctAnswer: Reverence for God's holiness and humility before His presence
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:2 shows the seraphims covering their face and feet, symbolizing awe and respect for God's absolute holiness, which is a common ancient Near Eastern motif indicating reverence and recognition of divine majesty.

questions.question: The thrice-repeated 'Holy, holy, holy' in Isaiah 6:3 employs which Hebrew literary device?
options: Intensification through repetition (superlative form)
Parallelism of ideas
Chiasmus
Inclusion
questions.correctAnswer: Intensification through repetition (superlative form)
questions.explanation: The triple repetition in Isaiah 6:3 is a Hebrew rhetorical device to emphasize the absolute holiness of God, signaling a superlative degree of sanctity beyond ordinary holiness.

questions.question: The movement of the doorposts and filling of the temple with smoke in Isaiah 6:4 metaphorically represents what phenomenon in the ancient Israelite worship context?
options: The overwhelming presence and power of God
The beginning of a sacrificial ritual
A natural earthquake during the vision
The arrival of the High Priest
questions.correctAnswer: The overwhelming presence and power of God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:4 uses vivid imagery—moving doorposts and smoke—to symbolize the awe-inspiring and consuming presence of God in the temple, an expression of divine majesty and holiness.

questions.question: Isaiah's confession in Isaiah 6:5 acknowledges his unworthiness. This humility echoes which New Testament concept?
options: Recognition of sinfulness before God as seen in the tax collector's prayer in Luke 18:13
The Beatitudes
The Great Commission
Faith without works
questions.correctAnswer: Recognition of sinfulness before God as seen in the tax collector's prayer in Luke 18:13
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:5's confession of unclean lips parallels the humility expressed in the tax collector's prayer in Luke 18:13, highlighting awareness of sinfulness and need for God's mercy.

questions.question: The live coal taken from the altar and placed on Isaiah's lips in Isaiah 6:6-7 signifies what theological theme?
options: Purification and atonement for sin
Judgment upon the people
A call to war
Divine wrath
questions.correctAnswer: Purification and atonement for sin
questions.explanation: The live coal in Isaiah 6:6-7 symbolizes cleansing and purification, a ritual act foreshadowing the atonement of Isaiah's sins, enabling him to serve as God's prophet.

questions.question: When the Lord says, 'Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?' in Isaiah 6:8, which New Testament passage echoes this commissioning language?
options: Jesus' Great Commission in Matthew 28:19-20
Paul's conversion in Acts 9
John's baptism in Matthew 3
Peter's confession at Caesarea Philippi
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus' Great Commission in Matthew 28:19-20
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:8's commissioning question parallels Jesus' sending of the disciples in Matthew 28:19-20, emphasizing the call to serve as God's messengers to the world.

questions.question: The instruction in Isaiah 6:9-10 to make the people's heart fat and ears heavy serves what prophetic purpose?
options: To harden the people's hearts as judgment for their disobedience
To prepare them for repentance
To encourage them to seek God
To bless them with understanding
questions.correctAnswer: To harden the people's hearts as judgment for their disobedience
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:9-10 describes a divine act of judicial hardening, where the people's spiritual insensitivity results from their persistent rejection of God's message.

questions.question: Isaiah's question 'Lord, how long?' in Isaiah 6:11 reflects what common prophetic concern?
options: The duration of divine judgment and suffering
The timing of the Messiah's arrival
The end of the exile
The destruction of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The duration of divine judgment and suffering
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:11 shows the prophet seeking clarity on how long God's judgment will last, reflecting a common theme in prophetic literature concerning the endurance of hardship before restoration.

questions.question: The 'tenth' that remains in Isaiah 6:13 is interpreted by scholars as symbolizing what?
options: A remnant preserved by God for restoration
A tithe given to the temple
A portion destroyed by fire
A group exiled to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant preserved by God for restoration
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:13 speaks of a tenth left, symbolizing a faithful remnant that survives judgment and becomes the foundation for future renewal and hope.

questions.question: The imagery of the 'teil tree' and 'oak' in Isaiah 6:13 serves as a metaphor for what theological concept?
options: Endurance and hidden strength of the holy seed (remnant)
The fertility of the promised land
God's wrath against Israel
The fleeting nature of human life
questions.correctAnswer: Endurance and hidden strength of the holy seed (remnant)
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:13 uses trees known for their resilience to symbolize the holy seed's enduring life and strength despite the judgment around them.

questions.question: True or False: The calling of Isaiah in chapter 6 foreshadows the New Testament concept of prophetic commissioning and readiness to serve God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:8 foreshadows the New Testament theme of prophetic commissioning where the servant answers God's call with 'Here am I; send me,' paralleling calls to ministry in the New Testament.

questions.question: The Hebrew word 'seraphim' in Isaiah 6:2 is related to which possible meaning, based on Hebrew etymology and ancient Near Eastern symbolism?
options: Burning ones, indicating their fiery and purifying nature
Messengers of peace
Guardians of the temple gates
Warrior angels
questions.correctAnswer: Burning ones, indicating their fiery and purifying nature
questions.explanation: The term 'seraphim' likely derives from a root meaning 'to burn,' reflecting their role as fiery beings associated with purification, as seen in the coal touching Isaiah's lips (Isaiah 6:6-7).

questions.question: The phrase 'the whole earth is full of his glory' in Isaiah 6:3 anticipates which New Testament declaration about God's glory?
options: The manifestation of God's glory in Jesus Christ (John 1:14)
The destruction of the earth at the end times
The temple's physical glory
The glory of the apostles' miracles
questions.correctAnswer: The manifestation of God's glory in Jesus Christ (John 1:14)
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:3's universal filling of earth with God's glory prefigures the incarnation where 'the Word became flesh and dwelt among us,' revealing divine glory in the New Testament (John 1:14).

questions.question: The phrase 'the house was filled with smoke' in Isaiah 6:4 evokes imagery reminiscent of which Old Testament theophany event?
options: Mount Sinai when God gave the Ten Commandments (Exodus 19:18)
Noah's flood
The burning bush
David's anointing by Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: Mount Sinai when God gave the Ten Commandments (Exodus 19:18)
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:4's smoke filling the temple recalls the Sinai theophany where smoke and fire symbolized God's majestic and terrifying presence during covenant revelation.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Isaiah's vision, how is the Lord described in relation to His throne?
options: Sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up
Standing beside a throne, low and humble
Reclining on a throne, hidden by clouds
Walking around a throne, surrounded by angels
questions.correctAnswer: Sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:1 describes the Lord as 'sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up,' emphasizing God's exalted sovereignty and majesty, consistent with other Scripture like Psalm 11:4 and Revelation 4:2-3.

questions.question: What covering did the seraphim use over their faces and feet, and what does this signify?
options: With twain they covered their face and feet; signifying reverence and holiness
With one wing they covered their eyes; signifying judgment
With all wings they covered their bodies; signifying protection
They uncovered their faces and feet; signifying openness
questions.correctAnswer: With twain they covered their face and feet; signifying reverence and holiness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:2 states the seraphim covered their faces and feet with two wings each, symbolizing the overwhelming holiness of God and reverence before Him, paralleling Psalm 99:5 and Exodus 3:5 where God's holiness demands reverence.

questions.question: What is the repeated declaration made by the seraphim in Isaiah's vision?
options: Holy, holy, holy, is the LORD of hosts
Glory, glory, glory, to the King
Mighty, mighty, mighty, is the God of Israel
Blessed, blessed, blessed, be His name
questions.correctAnswer: Holy, holy, holy, is the LORD of hosts
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:3 records the seraphim proclaiming 'Holy, holy, holy,' emphasizing the absolute holiness of God, a theme echoed in Revelation 4:8 and Leviticus 11:44, highlighting God's unique moral purity.

questions.question: What effect did the voice of the one crying have on the temple structure?
options: The posts of the door moved
The walls crumbled
The roof opened
The floor shook
questions.correctAnswer: The posts of the door moved
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:4 mentions the doorposts moving at the voice, illustrating the powerful presence of God, consistent with the shaking of Sinai in Exodus 19:18 and the trembling at the voice of God in Hebrews 12:26.

questions.question: How does Isaiah respond upon seeing the Lord, and what theological principle does this express?
options: Woe is me! for I am undone; expressing human sinfulness in the presence of divine holiness
Joy fills my heart; expressing assurance of salvation
I am strengthened; expressing divine empowerment
Fear overtakes me; expressing judgment without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Woe is me! for I am undone; expressing human sinfulness in the presence of divine holiness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:5 shows Isaiah's confession of unworthiness before God’s holiness, highlighting the doctrine of human sinfulness and need for cleansing, parallel to Job 42:6 and Romans 3:23.

questions.question: What did the seraphim use to cleanse Isaiah's lips, and what does this symbolize?
options: A live coal from the altar; symbolizing purification and atonement
Water from a river; symbolizing cleansing and renewal
A feather from a dove; symbolizing peace and innocence
Oil from a lamp; symbolizing anointing and empowerment
questions.correctAnswer: A live coal from the altar; symbolizing purification and atonement
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:6-7 describes the use of a live coal from the altar to touch Isaiah’s lips, symbolizing the purifying power of God’s holiness and atoning sacrifice, consistent with Leviticus 16:12-13 and Hebrews 9:13-14.

questions.question: What was the immediate effect on Isaiah after the seraph touched his lips with the coal?
options: His iniquity was taken away, and his sin purged
He was filled with the Holy Spirit
He was given a prophetic vision
He was healed of physical ailments
questions.correctAnswer: His iniquity was taken away, and his sin purged
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:7 says the coal touched Isaiah's lips and purged his sin, showing the principle of divine forgiveness and sanctification, aligned with 1 John 1:9 and Psalm 51:7.

questions.question: What question does the Lord ask after cleansing Isaiah, and what is Isaiah's response?
options: Whom shall I send? And who will go for us? Isaiah responds, 'Here am I; send me.'
Who will serve in my house? Isaiah responds, 'I am ready.'
Who will proclaim my word? Isaiah responds, 'I will do it.'
Who will be my witness? Isaiah responds, 'Send me forth.'
questions.correctAnswer: Whom shall I send? And who will go for us? Isaiah responds, 'Here am I; send me.'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:8 records God's call and Isaiah’s willing response, exemplifying the doctrine of divine calling and human obedience, consistent with Jeremiah 1:6-7 and Acts 13:2-3.

questions.question: What mission does God give Isaiah concerning the people’s hearing and understanding?
options: To tell them they will hear but not understand, see but not perceive
To bring them healing and restoration immediately
To teach them in parables that they may understand
To call them to repentance and immediate conversion
questions.correctAnswer: To tell them they will hear but not understand, see but not perceive
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:9 explains God’s commission that Isaiah’s message will result in hardened hearts, illustrating the prophetic theme of judgment and spiritual blindness, similar to Ezekiel 12:2 and Matthew 13:14-15.

questions.question: What is the purpose of making the people’s heart fat, ears heavy, and eyes shut?
options: So they will not convert and be healed
So they will be protected from evil
So they will understand deeply
So they will rejoice in the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: So they will not convert and be healed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:10 reveals that spiritual hardening prevents repentance and healing, underscoring divine judgment and human responsibility, consistent with Romans 1:24-28 and John 12:40.

questions.question: How long is Isaiah told to continue his prophetic ministry of warning?
options: Until the cities be wasted without inhabitant and the land utterly desolate
For a period of seventy years
Until the coming of the Messiah
Until Israel repents and returns to God
questions.correctAnswer: Until the cities be wasted without inhabitant and the land utterly desolate
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:11 states the duration of judgment, reflecting God's patience and justice, in line with Jeremiah 25:11 and Ezekiel 4:6 concerning exile and desolation.

questions.question: What does Isaiah say will happen to the land in the midst of the judgment?
options: There will be a great forsaking in the midst of the land
It will flourish and be blessed abundantly
It will be restored immediately
It will be given to foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: There will be a great forsaking in the midst of the land
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:12 describes the land being forsaken during judgment, demonstrating the consequences of sin and exile, paralleled in Lamentations 5:17 and Hosea 9:3.

questions.question: What does the 'tenth' mentioned in Isaiah 6:13 symbolize in the context of judgment and restoration?
options: A remnant that remains holy and will return
A tithe offered to the priests
Ten cities spared from destruction
Ten tribes that will be lost forever
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant that remains holy and will return
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:13 speaks of a tenth that remains, symbolizing the faithful remnant preserved by God, a key theme in biblical theology seen also in Romans 11:5 and Zechariah 10:12.

questions.question: How does Isaiah describe the holy seed in relation to the remnant after judgment?
options: As the substance and life within the remnant, like a tree with roots
As completely destroyed and forgotten
As scattered beyond recovery
As hidden and inactive
questions.correctAnswer: As the substance and life within the remnant, like a tree with roots
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:13 compares the holy seed to the vitality within a tree, illustrating God’s sustaining power over His people, consistent with Jeremiah 23:5-6 and John 15:5.

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s holiness is primarily revealed through the seraphim’s proclamation?
options: God is thrice holy, emphasizing absolute purity and moral perfection
God is holy only in judgment
God’s holiness is symbolic, not literal
God’s holiness is limited to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God is thrice holy, emphasizing absolute purity and moral perfection
questions.explanation: Isaiah 6:3’s triple 'holy' emphasizes God's supreme holiness, foundational for Christian doctrine as echoed in Revelation 4:8 and Leviticus 19:2, affirming God’s transcendence and moral perfection.
